text.p: Following are the main stories in Slovenia's Friday morning newspapers:
- Slovenian truck drivers blocked the border crossing Dolga Vas between Slovenia and Hungary to protest against the prolonged administration procedures carried out by Hungarian customs officials.
- The government said it would increase charges for domestic telephone calls by 8.6 percent on Monday, while international calls will be 18 percent cheaper.
- Slovenian parliamentary parties are expected to sign an agreement on changes to the constitution on Tuesday which would allow foreigners to buy land.
- President Milan Kucan attended a meeting of 25,000 pensioners in the city of Celje on Thursday.
- Nine NATO countries still believe Slovenia and Romania should be included in the first round of the alliance's expansion, the French press agency reported on Thursday.
- Ljubljana city council will debate the suggested removal of some communist monuments in the capital at its current session, which started on Thursday.
- Foreign Minister Zoran Thaler met his Italian counterpart Lamberto Dini in Rome on Thursday. They discussed Slovenia's bids to join NATO and the EU as soon as possible.
- Employees of the small private television channel TV3 said they would go on strike on Saturday to protest against unpaid salaries in the past six months.
- The police said more than 10 students of the police high school were taking drugs.
- Drug maker Krka said on Thursday it would pay a dividend of 500 tolars per share within 30 days.
- French company Filtrauto, which is a part of international group Labinal, is expected to buy the troubled Slovenian car and industrial filter maker Donit Filtri.
